Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering University of Malaya Kuala Lumpur 50603 Malaysia Catalytic gas-phase reactions have gained industrial applicability in the production of chemicals, fuels, and environmental remediation. However, conventional heterogeneous catalysts for gas-phase reactions contain precious metals, which have low utilization efficiency of metal atoms and are expensive, and therefore need to be improved to achieve industrial scalability. Therefore, single-atom catalysis has emerged as a new paradigm for dispersing isolated noble metals on a suitable support material. Herein, this review analyzed recent advances in single-atom catalysts (SACs) for oxidation of carbon monoxide, abatement of formaldehyde, reduction of nitrogen oxides, and hydrogenation of carbon dioxide. Various synthesis methods of different SACs were elucidated and highlighted for the thermochemical gas-phase reactions. Furthermore, the mechanism, challenges, and prospects of the SACs for gas-phase reactions were described. This review is significant to serve as a reference for current and prospective thermochemical gas-phase reactions driven by SACs. Due to their added value in the industry, the manufacture of platform chemicals and fuel drop-ins are among the most active and gray areas of the chemical industry [5]. The conventional synthetic means of producing platform chemicals or fuel drop-ins usually involve the use of either hazardous catalysts that pollutes the environment, or catalyst that is not selective but produces unwanted by-products which exceed the quantity of desired products produced. Considering the growing concerns about the environment and safety, there is an urgent need to develop efficient, catalysts for the synthesis of environmentally friendly and sustainable platform chemicals [6]. As a result, numerous effective synthesis techniques emerged to support the development of the chemical industry. However, these techniques are constrained by their sensitivity to moisture and/or air as well as their difficulty in being separated from the products, which can occasionally result in product contamination. To solve these issues, heterogeneous catalysts assisted by transition metal nanoparticles have been used. However, compared to their homogeneous analog, their total catalytic efficiencies are often lower. Therefore, the creation of a novel class of catalysts that combines the advantages of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts is imperative for the environmentally friendly synthesis of platform molecules. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) contain isolated metal atoms that are functionalized on support materials to promote catalytic activities [7–9]. Since the report that showed Pt1/FeOx SAC was three times more active than its nanoparticle Pt counterpart for oxidation of carbon monoxide [10], single-atom catalysis has emerged as a new paradigm in heterogeneous catalysis. Intrinsically, SACs are different from ordinary nanoparticle catalysts since they do not contain metal-metal bonds but single metal atoms. The interactions with reactants and intermediaries are significantly altered by these special geometrical and electrical features of SACs, resulting in increased activity and selectivity for the manufacture of platform chemical or catalytically driven environmental remediation. So, for the environmentally friendly synthesis of platform compounds, SACs are anticipated to combine the benefits of high catalytic activity, selectivity, stability, and reusability. Many SACs have been created with outstanding catalytic performance for a range of organic transformations, including selective hydrogenation, oxidation, and C-C coupling reactions. For instance, Co(Fe)–N–C [11], Ni-N-C [12], and Fe-N-C [13], catalysts proved exceptional performance for selective hydrogenation or oxidation reactions. Overall, the SACs could achieve high atomic efficiency that significantly lowers the cost of catalytic processes. The SACs not only increase the use of metal active sites but lessens the amount of noble metal utilization, increase efficiency, and improve the catalytic selectivity [14]. There are some instances, where the SACs are alloys known as single-atom alloys (SAA) catalysts; the case of catalytically active metals such as Pt, Ni, Ir, and Pd are doped into the surface of less reactive host metals like Cu, Ag, and Au [15,16]. Regardless, it is desired to elucidate SACs activity for thermochemical gas-phase reactions since some investigations are ongoing as mentioned earlier. This review focused on the recent advances in SAC-catalysed thermochemical gas-phase reactions for the green synthesis of platform chemicals and environmental remediation. This is an area where SACs are anticipated to find extensive application, bridging the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis. The studies discussed herein are simple thermochemical model reactions such as oxidation of carbon monoxide, abatement of formaldehyde, reduction of nitrogen monoxide, reduction of nitrous oxide, hydrogenation of carbon dioxide, selective hydrogenation of acetylene, hydro-chlorination of acetylene, and water gas shift reaction. Although some detailed review accounts for SACs exist on their preparation methods and characterization techniques [17–23], specific ones such as thermochemical gas-phase reactions are lacking but discussed in this review. 2 Synthesis of single-atom catalysts In this section, general methods of synthesis of SACs; such as the wet chemical method, atomic layer deposition, flame spray pyrolysis, and spatial confinement were discussed. These are motivated by the requirement for SAC formation through scattering isolated noble metal atoms onto the suitable support material. Moreover, contemporarily, advances in characterization techniques have made it easier to confirm the presence of isolated metal atoms which allows for a better understanding of their structure, stability, and catalytic potentials [14]. 2.1 Wet chemical method The wet chemical method is advantageous as it is readily accessible in any wet chemistry laboratory and requires no specially designed equipment [24–26]. This is an easy SACs synthesis technique that can be scaled for mass production. Wet chemistry methods are the focal point of most studies including; impregnation, co-precipitation, deposition-precipitation, redox precipitation, and galvanic replacement as depicted in Fig. 1 . 2.1.1 Impregnation This is a straightforward and economic method used to synthesize SACs. Specifically, an exact volume of the solution made up of the noble metal precursors is mixed with the support material (see Fig. 2 a). This is to enable the metal precursor to anchor onto the support by ion exchange or adsorption process [25,40]. For instance, single Pd atoms on CeO2 support catalysts [41] were synthesized using the impregnation method through the addition of Pd precursors solution into a ceria aqueous dispersion. The resulting catalysts were washed and dried at 80 °C overnight and further calcined in air at 350 and 800 °C for eight hours denoted as Pd1/CeO2_350 and Pd1/CeO2_800, respectively. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) result substantiated the dominance of the Pd-O bond as well as the absence of Pd-Pd bonding in both catalysts validating the atom dispersion of Pd in both catalysts. The improved oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface of Pd1/CeO2_800 catalyst was caused by the 800 °C calcination resulting in decreased Pd-CeO2 coordinations in square-planar Pd1O4. After impregnation and oxidation treatment of CeO2-supported Pt SACs at different temperatures, the surface area of the SAC decreases as the temperature increases from 120 to 500 °C while the pore volume remains unchanged [42]. The calcination of Pt1/CeO2 SAC at 500 °C caused complete decomposition of the surface (PtCl6-yOy) complexes which led to the strong interaction between Pt species with the support to yield Ce1-xPtxO2-y solid solution. CeO2-Al2O3 Pt SACs were synthesized after the reduction from 100 to 500 °C while reduction at 600 °C formed Pt nanoparticles [43]. The reduction temperature of 500 °C yielded very metallic Pt SAC with Pt0 of about 84 at%. CeO2-supported Pt SAC synthesized through the impregnation method followed by steam treatment at 750 °C did not influence the valences or dispersion of Pt [44]. It is difficult to prepare SAC through an impregnation method that can be stable on various support materials. To solve this challenge, the use of ligands to stabilize and chemically fix the single noble metal in the support materials [17,45]. For example, a series of single Pt atoms stabilized by sodium through -O ligands on different support (TiO2, KLTL zeolite, and MCM41) using the impregnation method [46]. The sodium-free Pt catalysts have abundant Pt nanoparticles on all three supports. There is a higher chance of finding Pt nanoparticles on MCM41 than TiO2 because TiO2 has strong metal-support interaction than Al2O3 or SiO2 resulting in higher dispersion of Pt. The sodium-containing Pt catalysts are free of Pt nanoparticles and without Pt-Pt bonding based on the XAS analysis. Titania anchored single atom Pt-ligand catalysts were synthesized by the impregnation method with three different organic ligands. These ligands are; 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione (PDO), 2,2’-di(2-pyridyl)-1, Bipyridine-5,5’-dicarboxylic acid (BDA), and 3,6-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (DPT) [47]. The XAS results of Pt-ligand catalysts on TiO2 showed clear signals of Pt-N/O and Pt-Cl coordination, but no Pt-Pt or Pt-Ti scattering indicating the absence of nanoparticles. The same Pt loading is obtained with PDO (0.62 wt% Pt) and BDA (0.62 wt% Pt) but a significantly lower Pt content is achieved when DPT (0.26 wt% Pt) is used as a ligand which may be due to the relatively weak σ donor strength of DPT. High-loading Pt SACs prepared through the impregnation method with alkali stabilizer (CsOH and KOH) had only O species coordinating with Pt and without Pt-Pt bonding [38]. Impregnation can be applied to nearly any support and metal species [26]. The kind of SAC synthesized using this method depends mainly on the active metal-support interaction [25]. 2.1.2 Co-precipitation This is where the metal precursor is precipitated together with the support. Co-precipitation is one of the most dependable methods to prepare metal oxide-based support single atom since all the metal oxide support are synthesized from their metal salts precipitation in alkaline solution (see Fig. 2b) [26,48]. For instance, isolated Ir atoms supported on iron oxide catalyst were prepared using coprecipitation with an aqueous mixture of Fe(NO3)3 and H2IrCl2 as the metal precursor using sodium hydroxide solution as the precipitation agent at 80 °C giving a pH of about 8 [49]. The resulting precipitate was then filtered, washed, and dried overnight at 80 °C and reduced with 10% H2/He at 300 °C for 30 min. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) image revealed that the individual Ir atoms were well-dispersed and exactly occupied the position of the Fe atoms. Recently, single Pt atoms supported on CeO2 catalyst were synthesized using the coprecipitation method [50]. The STEM image of the resultant catalyst did not show the formation of Co clusters. Hydrogen reduction at 550 °C for Pt1/CeO2 SAC brings about the emergence of very dispersed Pt nanoparticles. In general, co-precipitation is a straightforward, quick, and cheap method for SAC synthesis [25]. However, a drawback of this method is some of the active noble metal atoms may be misused as they are implanted into the bulk support [51]. 2.1.3 Deposition-precipitation The deposition-precipitation method is almost identical to impregnation in that this method needs the dispersion of the support in the metal precursor solution. But the metal species are furthermore precipitated to metal carbonate or hydroxide by modifying the pH value of the solution. The metal precursors at low noble metal loading rapidly attach to the oxide surface forming evenly distributed SAC after treatment [26,52]. For instance, Ir single-atom catalyst was prepared using the deposition-precipitation method in which the Ir precursor was anchored on the α-phase of molybdenum carbide (α-MoC) [53]. From the HAADF-STEM image, Ir single atoms were observed to be dispersed either on α-MoC(200) or α-MoC(111). There were no detectable Ir nanoparticles. From XAS analysis, there were no Ir-O or Ir-Ir bond contributions but the Ir-C and Ir-Mo bonds present with coordination numbers of 1.7 and 4.6, respectively validating Ir species are in a single atom state. Single Au atoms supported on defective TiO2 nanosheets and perfect TiO2 nanosheet catalysts were prepared through the deposition-precipitation method [54]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and HAADF-STEM results confirmed the formation of dispersed single Au atoms on both TiO2 supports. From the DRIFTS and DFT analysis, the Au atom is anchored on the perfect TiO2 nanosheet to bind with the surface Ti and O atoms creating a Ti-Au-O-Ti structure while the Au atom formed a Ti-Au-Ti structure in the defective TiO2 nanosheet. The relative binding energies calculations demonstrated that the Ti-Au-Ti structure has better stability than the Ti-Au-O-Ti structure. Single Rh atoms anchored on TiO2 were prepared through the deposition-precipitation method followed by acid leaching to dissolve the Rh nanoparticle leaving only Rh single atom on the TiO2 surface [35]. Using microcalorimetry and FTIR techniques to detect the CO adsorption, only two (2) peaks were detected at 2089 and 2019 cm−1 which are allocated to Rh(CO)2 gem-dicarbonyl species that occur exceptionally on isolated Rh sites. From BET results, metal loading and acid leaching inflicted hardly any influence on the support. The leaching treatment of the catalyst selectively retained the Rh single atoms with higher density dispersion with strong interaction with TiO2 support. 2.1.4 Redox precipitation This method uses hydrogen peroxide to create surface defects on the surface of the support through chemical etching and is filled with noble metals as single atoms (see Fig. 2c). For example, Au SAC on MnO2 support was synthesized using redox precipitation in which AuCl4 solution was added into α-MnO2 nanorod with dissolved water [55]. Concentrated hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) was added dropwise into the HAuCl4 and α-MnO2 mixture. Through H2O2 addition, a lot of O2 was released. After the redox precipitation, the catalyst was filtered, washed and dried at 200 °C for two hours. From the HAADF-STEM result, 0.25 wt% Au/α-MnO2 catalyst showed no aggregation of the Au species. A series of single Cu atoms anchored on MnO2 were prepared using the redox precipitation method at different metal loading [39]. It was verified by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of 3 wt%-Cu1/MnO2, that Cu species were well dispersed on the surface of MnO2. XAS and RAMAN results showed that some Mn atoms were replaced by Cu on the surface to establish the Cu-O-Mn structure. The Cu-O-Mn structure is inclined to higher valence, which additionally builds stronger interaction and stabilizes the SAC. 2.1.5 Sol-gel Sol-gel has been altered to prepare SAC on the metal oxide by incorporating the metal precursors in the starting materials [26,36]. For instance, Pt single-atom catalyst on mesoporous alumina (m-Al2O3) was prepared using the sol-gel method in which a mixture of H2PtCl6, aluminum isopropoxide, and pluronic P123 solution went through the sol-gel process to form a gel that calcined at different temperatures for four hours [36]. Transmission electron microscopy energy dispersive spectroscopy (TEM-EDS) and HAADF-STEM images demonstrated the existence of Pt atoms with high number density. From XAS analysis, the coordination number for both calcined and reduced Pt1/m-Al2O3 catalysts is 3.8–4.0 suggesting that each Pt atom is coordinated with four oxygen atoms on the support regardless of whether the catalyst is reduced or not. There was no direct bonding between Pt and Al in the EXAFS spectrum result indicating that Pt atoms bound to these sites through an oxygen bridge. The Pt content remained at about 0.2 wt% after thermal treatments at 600 and 800 °C which emphasizes Pt is strongly anchored in the m-Al2O3 support material. Generally, SAC synthesized using the sol-gel method display very good stability because active single metal atoms are strongly enclosed within the pores of the support, though part of the metal atoms may be implanted into the bulk of the oxide support. 2.1.6 Galvanic replacement This technique takes benefits of the semi-reduction capability of metal precursors which is used in single atom alloy synthesis. In galvanic replacement, the host metal act as a template for the noble metal precursor deposition through the metal exchange. The pre-reduction is required on the host metal surface for selective deposition of the noble metal [15,56]. For instance, Pd single-atom alloyed on Cu catalyst was prepared catalysts through galvanic replacement method [57]. The copper nanoparticles were prepared and anchored on γ-Al2O3 using Poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) as a stabilizer. The resulting material was calcined at 350 °C in the air for four hours. Galvanic replacement happened in an aqueous solution with constant stirring at 100 °C where the intended amount of Pt precursor was added to the copper nanoparticle suspension. After 20 min, the resulting catalyst was filtered, washed, and dried. From EXAFS analysis, no Pt-O and Pt-Pt bonds formed indicating the formation of Pt single atoms. 2.2 Atomic layer deposition This method allows for the synthesis of SAC at an atomic scale to be controlled. In the atomic layer deposition (ALD) process, the metal precursor vapor is pulsed into the chamber where it contacts and interacts with the metal oxide/carbon support (see Fig. 3 ). The by-products and unreacted metal precursors are either evaluated at a high vacuum and/or purged with inert gas. Increasing the number of pulsing cycles should be carefully considered because introducing more metal precursors would attach to the already formed single atoms leading to the formation of metal clusters [25,26,58,59]. Shi et al. [60] synthesized Cu-based SAC in which ALD of copper was performed on alumina support for one cycle at 250 °C. From the HAADF-STEM image of Cu1/Al2O3, it was found that all Cu species were atomically dispersed without the presence of Cu clusters. Carrying out three and five cycles of ALD of copper led to the formation of Cu clusters. EXAFS analysis showed that Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst has a Cu-O coordination number of about 4 and Cu-Cu coordination was not detected confirming the formation of Cu SAC. Pd single atoms on graphene and graphitic carbon-nitride (g-C3N4) support were synthesized using ALD for one cycle at 150 °C [61]. The HAADF-STEM results showed that individual Pt atoms were dispersed randomly on both support without any visible Pd clusters. For Pd1/C3N4 SAC, the EXAFS spectrum showed only one peak at 1.53 Å, which is assigned to the Pd-O/Pd-N coordination while no peak for Pd-Pd coordination was observed which is in agreement with the HAADF-STEM result. For Pd1/graphene SAC, the EXAFS spectrum showed two peaks in which the first one at 1.6 Å ascribed to Pd-C and Pd-O coordination, and the second peak at 2.5 Å was associated with Pd-Pd and Pd-C coordination. The Pd-Pd coordination number was approximately 0.5 suggesting the Pd nanoparticles were very low level. ALD provides several merits compared to other deposition techniques such as electrochemical deposition or chemical vapor deposition as follows; (i) ability to penetrate high surface area porous materials (ii) precise control of the thickness of a layer at the atomic level (iii) industrial scalability (iv) good reproducibility [26,58]. 2.3 Flame spray pyrolysis In this method, the metal and support precursors are well-mixed in a solution that permits homogenous mixing of all the precursors at the atomic level. The metal precursor solution and support then were atomized into liquid droplets by the atomizer and conveyed to the flame zone with the assistance of the carrier gas. The conversion of the precursor solution into solid catalysts happens through pyrolysis. The products are collected as a powder using quartz fiber filler [62–64]. For instance, Pt single atoms on different supports (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2, and TiO2) were prepared through the flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) method [63]. Pt single atoms were observed on Al2O3, ZrO2, and TiO2 among which ZrO2 showed the best stabilization of the dispersed Pt atoms. The dispersed single Pt atoms were enclosed into the ZrO2 matrix by substituting the Zr cations in the course of the FSP process. CeO2-supported single Pd atom catalysts were prepared using FSP and impregnation methods [64]. From the HAADF-STEM results, no Pd clusters were found on the Pd1/CeO2 FSP derived catalyst Using XPS, it was found that Pd1/CeO2-FSP had a lower Pd surface concentration than the impregnated catalyst. In the FSP method, it is possible that Pd atoms were doped on the surface and subsurface layer of the ceria. FSP has some merits to synthesize SAC; it is a cost-effective, single-step, and scalable method to manufacture catalysts at a kilogram scale per hour, and particle size and morphology of the catalysts can be controlled by adjusting the preparation condition [63]. 2.4 Spatial confinement Spatial confinement is an effective approach to fabricating SACs in which the segregation and encapsulation of the metal precursors with porous materials avoid the aggregation of single atoms into clusters. This method includes some steps: (i) preparation of porous material inclusive of covalent organic frameworks (COF), metal organic frameworks (MOF), and zeolites, (ii) incorporation of porous material and metal precursors, (iii) carbonization of the formulated material [25,65,66]. For instance, Co single atom on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (N-C) catalyst was synthesized using the spatial confinement method at 800 °C with high metal loading of 4 wt% [67]. HAADF-STEM image of Co1/N-C(800) showed that Co atoms have highly dispersed on N-C support. From the XRD results, no characteristic of Co crystals appeared when the preparation temperature was increased to 900 °C and the sample (Co1/N-C_900) maintained atomic dispersion of Co atoms which was confirmed by HAADF-STEM observation. When the preparation temperature was increased to 1000 °C, the crystalline Co phase existed confirming the Co nanoparticle formation. From XAS analysis, the coordination number of Co-N in Co1/N-C_800 and Co1/N-C_900 was 4 and 2, respectively. This is because a particular amount of Co-N coordination bonds were broken resulting from the increase in pyrolysis temperature. Pd single-atom anchored on mesoporous imine-linked COF catalyst was prepared using the spatial confinement method with high loading of Pt of 18.1 wt% [68]. The surface area of Pd1/ILCOF reduced from 2620 to 1640 m2/g as a result of the addition of Pt precursors. EXAFS analysis showed that the Pd atom was bound to two N and two Cl atoms, and no formation of the Pd-Pd bond. XPS results showed a similar spectrum for PdCl2 (1, 10- phenanthroline) and Pd1/ILCOF. The results from XPS and EXAFS determined that Pd is stabilized as an isolated single atom within the ILCOF pores. 3 Application of single-atom catalyst in thermocatalytic gas-phase reaction Studies on the application of single-atom catalyst in thermocatalysis in gas phase reactions such as oxidation, hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, hydrochlorination, water gas shift reaction (WGSR), hydrolysis, dry reforming of methane, etc are summarized in this section. 3.1 Catalytic oxidation 3.1.1 Oxidation of carbon monoxide Oxidation of carbon monoxide at low temperatures is of notable importance in practical applications such as the purification of gas streams acquired from the petrochemical industry and automobile emission control [69–71]. The oxidation of CO over CeO2 supported Pt single-atom catalysts have been widely reported as seen in Table 1 . Ceria-supported single Pt atoms catalysts were synthesized through the wetness impregnation method at different metal loading and calcination temperature of 300 and 500 °C [42]. The oxidation of CO increases over Pt1/CeO2 SAC (with Pt loading of 1.0 wt%) and decreases over Pt1/CeO2 SAC (with Pt loading of 0.5 wt%) as the calcination temperature increases. Ceria support single Pt atoms catalyst synthesized through impregnation method and activated with steam treatment had high thermal stability with no detectable deactivation during 310 h time on stream and maintained 95% CO conversion at 145 °C. [44]. Hydrogen reduction of co-precipitated ceria-supported Pt SAC at different temperatures revealed the formation of scattered Pt nanoparticles with higher oxygen vacancies occurring at 550 °C [50]. The co-precipitated Pt1/CeO2 SAC achieved complete oxidation of CO at a higher temperature compared with Pt/CeO2 nanoparticle catalyst. For wet CO oxidation, the activity of the Pt1/CeO2 SAC was extraordinarily enhanced by attaining 100% CO conversion at 98 °C. The presence of water in CO oxidation over Pt1/CeO2 SAC opens a new reaction path with a lower reaction barrier. The Pt1/CeO2 SAC showed good stability at 92 °C in water-promoted CO oxidation for 96 h. The HAADF-STEM result of the used ALD synthesized Pt1/CeO2 SAC had most of the single Pt atoms remaining after the stability test and only a few Pt clusters were noticed. Ascorbic acid aided reduction (AAAR) and impregnation methods were used to synthesize CeO2-supported Pt SACs (denoted as Pt1/CeO2_AAAR and Pt1/CeO2_IMP, respectively) [72]. The AAAR method uses the reductive ascorbic acid to cause abundant surface defects (ie Ce3+) which acts as an active site for Pt atoms to anchor and stabilized. Pt1/CeO2_AAAR presented higher activity (complete oxidation of CO at 60 °C) and had higher catalytic stability (no deactivation for 50 h on stream) compared to Pt1/CeO2_IMP (see Fig. 4 a). Pt single atoms catalysts were doped on different metal-oxides support (irreducible γ-Al2O3, reducible ZnO, and highly reducible Fe2O3) for oxidation of CO [73]. The catalytic activity of the Pt SACs was determined by the chemical properties of the support materials. The direct interaction of the single Pt atoms with the coordinative linked oxygen atoms of the support induces charge transfer between the Pt atom and the support. Such interaction adjusts the adsorption of the Pt atom and the reactivity of the support thus altering the catalytic performance of the SAC. The presence of water in CO oxidation highly reduces the influence of the supports on the catalytic performance of the Pt SACs. ZrO2-supported Pt SACs were synthesized through FSP and impregnation methods [63]. The impregnated Pt1/ZrO2 SAC had lower catalytic activity in CO oxidation than FSP-prepared Pt1/ZrO2 SAC. This is because the latter exhibited a mixed monoclinic-tetragonal ZrO2 support phase with enhanced redox ability. CeO2-Al2O3 supported Pt SACs synthesized through the impregnation method with varying oxidation states [43]. The highly oxidized Pt1/CeO2-Al2O3 SAC showed poor catalytic activity in CO oxidation than Pt/CeO2-Al2O3 nanoparticles catalyst while the metallic Pt1/CeO2-Al2O3 SAC showed higher activity. Pt1/CeO2-Al2O3 SAC reduced at 300 °C displayed the highest stability and activity for CO oxidation. Pt single atoms doped on mesoporous Al2O3 (m-Al2O3) catalyst through sol-gel method [36]. The Pt1/m-Al2O3 SAC preserved CO conversion of 100% at 400 °C for 225 h. No Pt nanoparticles were detected from spent Pt1/m-Al2O3 in the TEM analysis demonstrating that Pt species were uniformly dispersed spent Pt1/m-Al2O3 SAC. Pt single atoms supported on CeO2-TiO2 catalysts were synthesized through sol-gel and impregnation methods [80]. The sol-gel prepared Pt1/CeO2-TiO2 SAC presented good catalytic stability in CO oxidation upholding 100% CO conversion at 90 °C for 30 h. While the impregnated Pt1/ CeO2-TiO2 SAC had poor stability with a rapid decrease in oxidation of CO from 100 to 30% in 5 h at the same temperature as seen in Fig. 4b. The remarkable stability of sol-gel prepared Pt1/CeO2-TiO2 SAC was due to Pt atoms dispersedly confined in the CeO2-TiO2 phase junction. The sol-gel prepared Pt1/CeO2-TiO2 SAC achieved complete oxidation of CO at a lower temperature than Pt1/CeO2_AAAR and impregnated Pt1/CeO2-TiO2 catalysts. The oxidation of CO over ceria-supported Pd single-atom catalysts has also been widely studied as seen in Table 1. Ceria-supported Pd single atoms catalyst synthesized through impregnation method at different calcination temperatures [41]. The Pd1/CeO2_800 SAC (calcined at 800 °C) showed higher reactivity in low-temperature CO oxidation than Pd1/CeO2_350 SAC, ceria supported Pd nanoparticle catalyst and co-precipitated Pd/CeO2 catalyst. The presence of coordination-unsaturated Pd2+ in Pd1/CeO_800 SAC due to atom trapping was more reactive than Pd1/CeO_350 SAC although the latter has a higher surface area. CeO2 supported single Pd atoms catalysts, Pd1/CeO2_IMP (prepared through impregnation) and Pd1/CeO2_FSP (prepared through FSP) showed higher CO oxidation than Pd/SiO2 catalyst (with Pd loading of 5 wt%) under identical conditions (see Fig. 4c) [64]. The higher activity of the SACs is due to the presence of Pd-O single atom species. EXAFS and HAADF-STEM results displayed the formation of Pd clusters on spent Pd1/CeO2_IMP whereas no Pd-Pd bond was found in spent Pd1/CeO2_FSP. The oxidized Pd atoms in Pd1/CeO2_IMP were prone to sintering during CO oxidation while they remained intact on the surface of the Pd1/CeO2_FSP. Iridium, ruthenium, palladium, and rhodium single atoms supported on ceria catalysts were synthesized through the impregnation method for CO oxidation [76]. For the catalyst Rh, Ru and Ir supported on CeO2, the nanoparticle catalysts were more active than their SACs while for Pd catalyst, Pd SAC had higher activity than Pd nanoparticle and Pd nanoclusters. These differences in the catalytic active sites were connected to the diverse electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) of the noble metals doped on CeO2 support. CeO2-supported Au SAC was synthesized through impregnation with the electrostatic adsorption method [84]. Au1/CeO2 SAC achieved complete oxidation of CO at 20 °C higher temperature compared to Au1/Fe2O3 SAC [84]. CO conversion of 98% was maintained over Au1/Fe2O3 SAC at 200°C for 100 h due to the EMSI of the Au doped on Fe2O3. While CO conversion on Au1/CeO2 SAC rapidly decreased from 100 to 35% in about 6 h at 160 °C. Although Au1/CeO2 SAC is extensively sensitive to the presence of water making the SAC stable for the oxidation of CO. Single Au atoms supported on defective TiO2 nanosheet through deposition-precipitation method creating the Ti-Au-Ti structure [54]. The Ti-Au-Ti structure does not only hold up the stability of the single Au atom but also improves the catalyst properties in which it achieved complete CO oxidation at 120 °C. Whereas a single Au atom doped on a perfect TiO2 nanosheet achieved CO oxidation at 230 °C. Co3O4 supported single Au atoms catalyst was synthesized through the impregnation method followed by leaching with sodium cyanide [86]. Au1/Co3O4 SAC achieved complete CO oxidation at a very low temperature of -84 °C although the pure Co3O4 achieved complete CO oxidation at -25 °C as seen in Fig. 4d. The existence of the isolated Au atoms is responsible for the extreme activity of the Au1/Co3O4 SAC. Various cobalt-based nanoarrays supported by Pd single-atom catalysts were synthesized through the impregnation method [75]. Pd SAC doped on interlaced CoxOy nanoneedles (CoxOy-I) maintained CO conversion of 78% at 60 °C for 118 h whereas Pd SAC doped on bifurcate with CoxOy nanowire (CoxOy-B) at the same temperature for 113 h (see Fig. 4e). The high activity of Pd1/CoxOy-I SAC is due to rich oxygen vacancies of CoxOy-I support for trapping Pd single atoms and resulted in forming a 3D configured catalyst. The presence of water in the gas feed decreased the CO conversion on the CoxOy nanoarrays. While all Pd1/CoxOy SAC displayed higher activity during oxidation of CO in the presence of water. Copper single atoms doped on MnO2 catalysts with different Cu loading synthesized through redox precipitation for CO oxidation [39]. Cu1/MnO2 SAC (with Cu loading of 3 wt%) had the best catalytic activity and stability having maintained CO conversion of 100% at 100 °C for 13 h. The high activity was a result of the Cu-O-Mn active site exposed by redox precipitation which increases the active oxygen species that is favorable in activating the reactant. Silver single atom supported over antimony-doped tin oxide (ATO) catalyst synthesized through impregnation with atom trapping [83]. Ag1/ATO SAC calcined at 500°C had slightly higher activity in CO oxidation than the Ag1/ATO SAC calcined at 800 °C. This difference resulted from the aging temperature that affected the grain size of ATO nanocrystalline. Though, no Ag sintering took place in both catalysts. While high-temperature aging treatment brought about severe deactivation of Al2O3 support silver catalyst. ZnO-supported Rh and Pt SAC were synthesized through the impregnation method for CO oxidation [88]. The CO conversion curve of Rh1/ZnO-nanoflakes SAC harmonizes with that of Rh1/ZnO-nanowire SAC indicating the high activity arising from dispersed atoms irrespective of the facets of ZnO support. The Pt1/ZnO SAC with similar metal loading exhibited lower CO oxidation activity than Rh1/ZnO-nanowire SAC which is consistent with cesium phosphomolybdic acid [89] and CeO2-supported SACs [87]. Rh1/ZnO SAC maintained CO conversion for 100 h without deactivation in the presence of hydrocarbons and water contaminants. Industrially produced H2 often contained a small amount of CO which severely poisons the Pt anode in H2-based fuel cells and also poisons the catalyst in other processes such as the Haber process. Preferential CO oxidation (PROX) is acknowledged as the most straightforward and economical approach to expel the remaining CO to a tolerable level (that is 50 ppm) [95–97]. FeOx-supported Ir SAC was synthesized through the impregnation method for PROX. The CO conversion in PROX over Ir1/FeOx SAC is unusually lower than FeOx-supported Pt SAC [30]. This is because Pt1/FeOx SAC has a lower reaction energy barrier than Ir1/FeOx SAC for oxidation of CO. Single Pt atom catalysts, Pt1-Ox-Cs/SiO2 and Pt1-Ox-K/Al2O3, were synthesized with alkali stabilizers through the impregnation method [38]. Pt1-Ox-Cs/SiO2 and Pt1-Ox-K/Al2O3 SAC showed remarkable PROX activity (CO conversion of 98 and 100% at 110 °C, respectively). While those catalysts without an alkali-comprising counterpart (Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/SiO2) had very poor activity (see Fig. 4f). The Pt1-Ox-Cs/SiO2 and Pt1-Ox-K/Al2O3 catalysts activate O2 and H2 to form -OH which improves CO oxidation through the water gas shift reaction pathway. CeO and FeOx-supported Au SACs were synthesized through the impregnation method for PROX [33]. The Au1/CeO2 (Au loading of 0.05 wt%) had higher activity and selectivity for PROX with 100% CO conversion over a broad temperature ranging from 80 to 120 °C than Au/CeO2 nanoparticles catalyst. Au1/FeOx SAC maintained CO conversion of 87% during PROX for 50 h at 80 °C without any detectable deactivation. While Au1/CeO2 SAC deactivates moderately with initial CO conversion from 49 to 37% after 41 h. Au1/CeO2 SAC was also deactivated after an early increase in conversion of CO indicating the presence of a massive quantity of CO2 has a negative effect. The impregnated Au1/CeO2 displayed higher activity at low temperatures than Au1/CeO2 SAC prepared through the ball milling method [90]. 3.1.2 Oxidation of formaldehyde Formaldehyde is a colorless gas and toxic pollutant. It mostly originates from the manufacture of materials such as pesticides, paints, printing materials, and automobile exhausts. Formaldehyde has severe harmful effects on human health. Removal of formaldehyde is essential to protect the atmospheric environment and human health [98]. Hollandite-type manganese oxide (HMO) supported silver and sodium single-atom catalysts were synthesized through the impregnation method for formaldehyde oxidation [93]. The Na1/HMO SAC exhibited higher catalytic activity than Ag1/HMO SAC. XPS and XAS results showed that the surface lattice oxygen of Ag1/HMO SAC has a lower electronic density than that of Na1/HMO SAC which is responsible for Na1/HMO SAC having higher efficiency in formaldehyde oxidation. Au single atom supported on α-MnO2 nanorod catalysts were synthesized through impregnation and redox precipitation methods for the oxidation of formaldehyde [55]. With the same Au loading, Au1/α-MnO2 SAC prepared by redox precipitation exhibited superior activity than the impregnated Au1/α-MnO2 SAC. The activation energy for oxidation of impregnated Au1/α-MnO2 catalyst was higher than that of Au1/α-MnO2 SAC prepared by redox precipitation. This affirms the feasibility of the redox precipitation method to synthesize competent catalysts for formaldehyde oxidation. 3.1.3 Oxidation of 2-propanol to acetone A series of Au alloyed Pd single atoms supported on titania catalysts were synthesized through the seed-mediated colloidal method [37]. In the oxidation of 3-propanol to acetone with the absence of hydrogen, Au/TiO2 nanoparticles catalyst had no activity until 125 °C while Pd/TiO2 nanoparticles catalyst had maximum activity at 75 °C. AuxPd SAA catalysts with a higher ratio of Pd content had higher activity at lower temperatures. With regards to selectivity, AuxPd SAA catalysts had 100% acetone selectivity at 125 °C whereas the Pd/TiO2 catalyst never attained 100% acetone selectivity due to the initiation of complete combustion close to 100 °C. In the presence of hydrogen in the feed, 2-propanol oxidation and acetone selectivity for all AuxPd SAA catalysts were improved to a different level. Pd/TiO2 catalyst did not display any improvement under the hydro-oxidation environment. The best improvement was noticed for Au37Pd/TiO2 SAA catalyst with hydro-oxidation activity higher than both pure metal catalysts. In terms of catalyst stability, Au37Pd/TiO2 SAA catalyst exhibited deactivation with the initial 2-propanol conversion from 33 to 4% after 25 h while maintaining acetone selectivity of 95%. Au12.5Pd/TiO2 SAA catalyst showed no sign of deactivation with a 2-propanol conversion of 76% and acetone selectivity of 95% after 41 h. 3.1.4 Oxidation of methanol to methyl formate Pd single atoms alloyed on Cu nanoparticles supported on silica catalysts through galvanic replacement method. SiO2-supported Pd nanoparticles exhibited high activity (methanol conversion of 35% at 130 °C) although methyl formate selectivity is fairly low. While Cu100Pd/SiO2 SAA catalyst has methanol conversion and methyl formate selectivity of 32.0 and 97%, respectively. The presence of isolated Pd atoms on the Cu surface significantly improved methyl formate selectivity. The Cu100Pd/SiO2 SAA catalyst also had high catalytic stability with a slight increase in methanol conversion from 33 to 34% and maintained methyl formate selectivity of 98% after 10 h. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenation 3.2.1 Hydrogenation of acetylene The selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethene continues to be a challenge of basic importance in the industry. Ethene streams from naphtha cracking units usually have approximately 0.1–1% of acetylene as a contaminant, which is essential to be reduced to less than 5 ppm since it deactivates the catalyst in the polymerization of ethene and sooner or later, degrades the produced polyethylene quality [99,100]. The hydrogenation of acetylene over single-atom catalysts has been broadly reported as seen in Table 2 . Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and graphene-supported Pd SACs were synthesized through the ALD method [61]. In the absence of ethene in the feed, Pd1/g-C3N4 SAC achieved complete acetylene conversion at about 20 °C higher temperature compared to Pd1/graphene SAC although Pd1/g-C3N4 catalyst exhibited higher ethene selectivity than Pd1/graphene catalyst which is due to the presence of a small amount of Pd nanoparticles in the Pd1/graphene catalyst. In the presence of excess ethene in the feed, the Pd1/g-C3N4 catalyst exhibited both higher ethene selectivity and higher coking resistance than the Pd nanoparticle catalyst [101]. Mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon nanosphere (MNCN) supported single Pd atom catalyst was prepared through the Lewis acid doping method [102]. Pd1/MNCN single-atom catalyst showed higher activity in semi-hydrogenation of acetylene than that of its non-mesoporous counterpart (Pd1/non-MNCN) catalyst by a factor of 4 although both catalysts have similar ethene selectivity. The Pd1/MNCN SAC exhibited good long-term catalytic stability in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene upholding acetylene conversion and ethene selectivity of 83% and 81%, respectively for 20 h at 110 °C. Palladium single-atom catalyst supported on Lewis base N8 on CNT substrate (Pd1/N8-CNT_CV) was prepared through the cyclic voltammetry method [103]. The Pd1/MNCN SAC exhibited good long-term stability in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene maintaining acetylene conversion and ethene selectivity of 83% and 81% ,respectively for 20 h at 110 °C. Palladium single atom catalyst supported on Lewis base N8 on CNT substrate (Pd1/N8-CNT_CV) was prepared through the cyclic voltammetry method [103]. Pd1/N8-CNT_CV catalyst had a high acetylene conversion of 83% at 40 °C whereas impregnated Pd/CNT and Pd/N8-CNT catalysts had very low acetylene conversion of 1% and 0.1%, respectively at the same temperature. Pd1/N8-CNT_CV catalyst had better catalytic performance than Pd1/MNCN SAC in which acetylene conversion of 83% and ethene selectivity of 98% was maintained for 20 h at 110 °C. Impregnated zinc oxide supported Pd SAC with Pd loading of 0.01 wt% displayed remarkable catalytic performance in semi-hydrogenation of acetylene with comparable ethene selectivity and increased activity to that of PdZn intermetallic catalyst [105,118]. Pd1/ZnO SAC with isolated Pd single sites will prevent ethene adsorption from σ‐bonding mode to the weak π‐bonding pattern owing to the geometric restraining effect, as a result avoiding the further hydrogenation of ethene to ethane. Hydroxyapatite-supported Pd SAC stabilized with ionic liquid (Pt1-BmimBF4/HAP) exhibited high durability and high ethylene selectivity over 90 h on stream with the acetylene conversion decreasing from 100 to 92% [104]. Whereas ionic liquid-free Pd1/HAP SAC showed much lower durability and ethylene selectivity, acetylene conversion decreased from 100 to 92% within 17 h. The presence of ionic liquid makes the aggregation of atoms thermodynamically less favourable and protects the isolated metal atoms. Alumina-supported Cu single-atom catalyst was synthesized through ALD method [60]. The Cu1/Al2O3 SAC showed outstanding ethene selectivity of 91% at full acetylene conversion together with remarkable long-term stability after 40 h. Whereas there was sudden deactivation on the Cu1/Al2O3 nanoparticles catalyst from initial acetylene conversion of 71–36% after 40 h. Pd single atoms alloyed on Ag nanoparticles supported on silica catalysts prepared through the impregnation method for hydrogenation of acetylene to ethene in excess ethene [106]. The selective hydrogenation of acetylene improved significantly with an increase in the reduction temperature of the AgxPd/SiO2 SAA catalysts. Ag100Pd/SiO2 and Ag40Pd/SiO2 SAA exhibited higher activity and ethene selectivity than Au alloyed Pd catalysts with the same Pd loading [32]. Additionally, ethene selectivity and acetylene conversion remained nearly unchanged over 24 h on-stream for Ag100Pd/SiO2, whereas acetylene conversion decreased by 22 % over the same period for Au100Pd/SiO2 SAA catalyst. Cu alloyed Pt single atoms supported on Al2O3 catalyst synthesized through a galvanic replacement for selective hydrogenation of acetylene in the presence of CO [109]. Pure Pt/Al2O3 nanoparticles suffered about 90% of their initial activity in the presence of CO while Cu125Pt/Al2O3 SAA catalyst only lost 50% of its catalytic activity (see Fig. 5 a). Silica-supported Cu alloying with single Pd atoms catalysts was synthesized through different preparation techniques [34]. All the prepared CuxPd/SiO2 SAA catalysts exhibited excellent activity and ethene selectivity as seen in Fig. 5b. Although the acetylene conversion of AgxPd/SiO2 SAA prepared through the galvanic replacement method was the highest, it decreased much more quickly during the stability test. The AgxPd/SiO2 SAA catalyst prepared by wetness impregnation technique was found to have the best all-inclusive catalytic performance. A series of Cu alloyed Pd single atoms supported on SiO2 catalysts were synthesized through impregnation method [107,108]. For the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethene, increasing the reduction temperature from 250 to 400 °C barely influenced the catalytic performance of the CuxPd/SiO2 compared to those of AgxPd/SiO2 SAA catalysts. Cu160Pd/SiO2 SAA catalyst displayed complete acetylene with ethene selectivity of 87% at 160°C. The CuxPd/SiO2 SAA catalyst exceeded both AgxPd/SiO2 and AuxPd/SiO2 SAA catalysts in acetylene conversion, while its ethene selectivity outperformed that of AuxPd/SiO2 catalysts and matched that of AgxPd/SiO2 catalyst. 3.2.2 Hydrogenation of 1,3- butadiene Graphene-supported single Pd atom catalyst was synthesized using ALD method [112]. Pd1/graphene SAC had higher butadiene conversion and butene selectivity than Pd1/g-C3N4 SAC [61]. It was found that irrespective of the hydrogen partial pressure, Pd1/graphene SAC exhibited 100% butene selectivity at close to ambient temperature. Alumina-supported single Cu atom catalyst was synthesized through the ALD method [60]. The Cu1/Al2O3 SAC exhibited outstanding catalytic stability with butene selectivity of 100% for 60 h which is better than Cu125Pt/Al2O3 SAA catalyst which was stable for at least 46 h [57]. Single-atom Pt catalyst stabilized by polyoxometalate on activated carbon was synthesized through wet chemistry and had higher selectivity towards butene but a lower conversion of propylene and 1,3-butadiene than polyoxometalate-free Pt catalyst [113]. Mesoporous Al2O3 supported Pt SAC synthesized through sol-gel converted butadiene to butene with 99% selectivity at 50 °C without influencing the co-feed propylene which was higher than commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [36]. 3.2.3 Hydrogenation of carbon dioxide Pd single-atom supported on Fe3O4 catalyst was synthesized through wet chemistry method for hydrogenation of CO2 [114]. It was observed that CO2 conversion was higher at increasing Pd loading. At the temperature of 300 °C, Pd1/Fe3O4 SAC exhibited remarkable selectivity toward ethanol (97.5%) but very low CO2 conversion (0.3%) whereas Pd/Fe3O4 clusters and nanoparticles catalysts exhibited high selectivity towards CO and had slightly higher CO2 conversion (1.0% and 1.2%, respectively). There is an evident relationship between Pd particle size and ethanol selectivity, the larger the Pd particle size, the lower the ethanol selectivity since the ethanol selectivity is promoted by the presence of Pd single atoms. The particle interaction established between Fe3O4 and Pd single-atom formulate specific active sites for C-C coupling. An increase in pressure (30 bar) led to an increase in CO2 conversion and, the highest selectivity to ethanol was acquired at 250 °C. α-MoC supported Pd single-atom catalyst was synthesized through the reduction carburization method [115]. The Pd1/α-MoC SAC exhibited high activity, outstanding selectivity, and excellent long-term stability for hydrogenation of CO2 to CO with CO selectivity decreasing very slightly from 99 to 98% at 400 °C after 40 h (see Fig. 5c). This was higher than the Pd/α-MoC nanoparticle catalyst (having CO selectivity of 33%). The STEM-HAADF images of Pd1/α-MoC SAC after CO2 hydrogenation (reverse-water gas shift) reaction showed that the Pd single atoms are still in existence after the reaction at high temperatures. A series of chalcogenide (sMoS2) supported Fe single-atom catalysts were synthesized by hydrothermal treatment. The Fe single-atom catalysts were atomically dispersed up to 10 wt% and after this loading, the formation of Pd clusters was perceived. For CO2 hydrogenation at 300 °C and 1 bar, the presiding product over Fe1/sMoS2 SAC catalyst was CO 100% selectivity. When the pressure was increased to 10 bar, the formation of methane was the chief by-product for all Fe/sMoS2 catalysts. Slightly amount (< 1%) of methanol, C2, and C3 hydrocarbons were noticed when Fe loading was increased higher than 10%. The Fe/sMoS2 SAC (with Fe loading of 10 wt%) displayed the best catalytic activity with CO selectivity of > 98% at 10 bar and 350 °C. The SACs were not capable to combine carbon species to form high carbon chains due to the well-dispersed nature of the Fe single atoms on the catalyst surface. 3.2.4 Hydrogenation of acrolein A series of Ag alloyed Pd single atoms supported on SiO2 catalysts were synthesized through co-impregnation for acrolein hydrogenation [117]. For similar particle sizes, the Ag800Pd/SiO2 SAA catalyst displayed higher allyl alcohol than its pure Pd counterparts. The DFT analysis indicated that the isolated single Pt atoms acted as a site for the suitable bonding of acrolein molecule for effortless hydrogenation of the aldehyde functional group. The selectivity of Pg100Pd/SiO2 is slightly lower than Ag800Pd/SiO2 catalyst, but the activity was double that of Ag800Pd/SiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic hydrochlorination Acetylene hydrochlorination is one of the economical methods for the industrial production of vinyl chloride. This industrial method uses mercury chloride supported on activated carbon as a catalyst but this catalyst has poor stability due to deactivation and mercury chloride causes environmental pollution [119]. There have been several studies on the hydrochlorination of acetylene over single-atom catalysts as seen in Table 3 . Single-atom Pd supported on N-doped carbon material (NC) catalysts were synthesized through the impregnation method [120]. The Pd SACs with no thermal treatment (Pd1/NC) and Pd with thermal treatment (Pd1/NC-TA) displayed conversion of acetylene of 99.5% and 95%, respectively, without deactivation after 600 min on steam (with flowrate = 1000 h−1) at 160 °C in comparison to Single-atom Pd supported on activated carbon having an initially low conversion of acetylene of 42% combined with rapid deactivation having acetylene conversion of 8% after 600 min. When the flow rate was increased from 1000 to 5000 h−1, Pd1/NC SAC having an initial acetylene conversion of 84% decreased rapidly to 50% after 5 h. HAADF-STEM analysis of the spent Pd1/NC SAC showed that it had lost about 39% Pd content. This deactivation of Pd1/NC catalyst resulted from the active site (PdCl2) having little or no bonding to pyridinic N. Whereas Pd1/NC-TA SAC maintained acetylene conversion of 88% at the same reaction conditions. The high stability of the Pd1/NC-TA catalyst is due to its active site PdClN having a high anchoring influence of Pd to pyridinic N. Impregnated graphitic carbon nitride supported single gold atom catalyst (Au1/g-C3N4) had higher acetylene conversion and better vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) selectivity in hydrochlorination of acetylene than the graphitic carbon nitride supported gold nanoparticles catalyst [121]. Also, the Au1/g-C3N4 SAC had higher catalytic stability in acetylene hydrochlorination than the Au/g-C3N4 nanoparticles catalyst. This is due to the SAC active site (Au1−N3) sites which cannot be reduced into Au0 state with ease and therefore maintain their catalytic activity. A series of Pt single-atom catalysts supported on different thermally treated activated carbon (AC) were synthesized through the impregnation method [122]. The Pt1/AC SAC with no AC treatment had acetylene TOF and vinyl chloride yield higher than those of the Pt1/AC SACs with AC treatment. The Pt SAC with activated carbon treated at 600 °C exhibited the highest catalyst stability in acetylene hydrochlorination while Pt1/AC SAC with no AC treatment was the least stable. The Ru1/AC-APS catalyst had long-term stability in which its conversion of acetylene decreased slightly from 96.9 to 96.0% after 600 h on stream. This is as a result of the oxidative treatment which induced the creation of defective structure on the support which makes available more anchoring sites for the Ru atoms. 3.4 Catalytic water gas shift reaction Iron oxide-supported Ir and Pt single-atom catalysts were synthesized through the coprecipitation method [49]. The Ir1/FeOx SAC was very active having higher TOF than the Pt1/FeOx SAC (Table 4). The Ir1/FeOx SAC maintained consistent conversion of CO (∼ 30%) in the water gas shift reaction (WGSR) at 300° for over 20 h of run despite its little decrease at the early stage. The HAADF-STEM analysis of the used Ir1/FeOx SAC consists of mainly dispersed Ir single atoms which were stable under standard WGSR circumstances. Pd single atoms supported on Al2O3 and FeOx catalysts were prepared through the coprecipitation method [124]. The Pd1/FeOx SAC exhibited higher CO conversion than Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with good stability even in the presence of H2 and CO2. The Pd single atoms considerably enhanced the FeOx reducibility and promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies which act as a site to boost H2O dissociation to produce H2. α-MoC-supported Pt single-atom catalyst was prepared using impregnation method exhibited 2.5 times higher CO conversion in WGSR at 200°C than the conventional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst [125]. Ir supported on α-MoC SAC was synthesized through the deposition-precipitation method and showed high activity for WGSR with about 100% CO conversion at 150 °C (see Fig. 6 a) [53]. α-MoC-supported Ir SAC had a higher specific reaction rate of about 48 times than FeOx-supported Ir SAC and four times that of α-MoC. The Ir single atom in Ir1/α-MoC SAC is not exactly associated with the catalysis but acts as a promoter. A series of hollow mesoporous ceria microsphere-supported single Au atom catalysts (Au1/CeO2-hm) with different loading were prepared through impregnation [126]. With the same Au loading, Au1/CeO2-hm displayed about 9 times more reactivity in WGSR than commercial CeO2 (CeO2-c) supported Au catalysts although their activation energies are the same. The defective sites of CeO2-hm do not affect the activity of WSGR directly. The effect of the defect sites of CeO2-hm increases the ability to scatter the Au atoms sites. Single-atom Pt catalysts were stabilized by Na through -O ligands on TiO2, mesoporous silica (MCM-41), and KLTL zeolite support [46]. The Na-free catalyst exhibited low WGS activity while Na-comprising Pt SACs (Pt-Ox-Na) had the same reaction rate for all three supports. The Pt-Ox-Na catalysts were stable and gave comparable CO conversion (50–60%) during 10 h test at 275 °C (see Fig. 6b). The used catalysts maintained their foundational Pt-Ox-Na structure. Remarkably, the dispersed Pt atoms were still the main species even for the less stable Pt-Ox-Na/MCM-41 catalyst after use. Titania-supported Rh single-atom catalyst (Rh1/TiO2-AL) was synthesized through deposition-precipitation followed by acid leaching [35]. The conversion of CO over Rh1/TiO2-AL SAC was similar to Rh/TiO2 nanoparticles catalyst in spite it being about seven times lower in Rh loading. The Rh1/TiO2-AL SAC displayed no methane production while it was evident on the Rh/TiO2 nanoparticles catalyst (see Fig. 6c). Rh single-atom promotes the formation of more oxygen vacancies on TiO2 support to activate H2O to form H2 and prevent H2 dissociation resulting in increased selectivity and activity for WGSR. The Rh1/TiO2-AL SAC has excellent catalytic stability under practical WGSR conditions at 300 °C maintaining 75% CO conversion and CH4 selectivity of 0% for 100 h in the presence of H2 and CO2. 3.5 Catalytic dry reforming of methane Nickel supported on hydroxyapatite (HAP) SACs were synthesized through impregnation with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and electrostatic adsorption (ESA) methods [127]. Ni1/HAP catalyst prepared with PVP had an initial CO2 conversion of 86% and merely decreased to 79% after 16 h of DRM reaction showing better catalytic stability than the Ni/HAP SAC prepared through ESA with CO2 conversing decreasing from 86 to 56% after 16 h. The deactivation of the latter catalyst was associated mainly with the sintering and aggregation of Ni single-atom rather than carbon deposit. The use of PVP in the catalyst's synthesis resulted in remarkable improvement in the catalyst stability. A series of ceria-doped hydroxyapatite-supported Ni SACs with different Ni loading were synthesized through the impregnation method [128]. The Ni1/HAP-Ce with Ni loading of 0.5 wt% had a moderate decrease from initial CO2 conversion of ∼90% after 65 h of DRM reaction. Whereas increasing the Ni loading over the support Ce-doped HAP, the Ni1/HAP-Ce SAC (with Ni = 2.0 wt%) has long-term stability which operated steadily at 95% of CO2 conversion for about 100 h. By comparison, the Ni/HAP-Ce nanoparticles catalyst (with Ni = 10.0 wt%) was quickly deactivated after fifteen hours on stream due to intense coking. The major role of Ce in the support is to stabilize the isolated atoms more than subdue carbon deposition. 3.6 Catalytic reduction of NO and N2O A series of iron oxide-supported Mo single-atom catalysts with different Mo loading were prepared through the impregnation method for selective catalytic reduction of NO with ammonia [129]. NO conversion in selective reduction (SR) increases with Mo loading while the acidic α-MoO3 and α-Fe2O3 alone have very low SR activities under similar reaction situations. Concurrently, the N2 selectivity of Fe2O3 significantly increases after the loading of single Mo atoms. Also, Mo1/Fe2O3 SAC displayed remarkable SO2 and/or H2O long-term stability. The activity trend of W1/Fe2O3 SAC is identical to that of Mo1/Fe2O3 SAC. But the activity of Mo1/Fe2O3 SAC is slightly higher than W1/Fe2O3 SAC which is evident that selective reaction rates are affected by the dinuclear sites (Table 5 ). Rh single atoms supported on CeO2 catalyst were prepared by impregnation through high-temperature atom trapping for selective reduction of NO with CO [130]. The Rh1/CeO2 SAC under dry (CO + NO) reaction conditions attained complete NO conversion at ∼100 °C and very little to no N2O formed above 120 °C. In the presence of H2O, Rh1/CeO2 attained complete NO conversion at ∼ 120 °C alongside ammonia and nitrogen being the main product with N2O as the minor product. The optimum selectivity of NH3 was 57% at a low temperature [39] of 112 °C. NH3 formation happens together with WGS activity of Rh1/CeO2 SAC which is due participation of rhodium hydride. The Rh1/CeO2 catalyst displayed remarkable stability with very slight deactivation from NO conversion of 97.8–94% after 174 h. Single Ir atoms supported on mesoporous WO3 (m-WO3) catalyst were prepared through a hard template method followed by the impregnation method for selective reduction of NO with CO [131]. The Ir1/m-WO3 SAC was very effective for the reduction of NO by CO in the presence of O2- rich environments attaining N2 selectivity of 100% and NO conversion of 73% at 350 °C. The turnover frequency of Ir1/m-WO3 was six times higher than the Ir/m-WO3 nanoparticles catalyst. the outstanding performance of Ir1/m-WO3 SAC is associated with the establishment of isolated Ir atoms on mesoporous WO3 and the existence of accessible mesopores in m-WO3 support that promote the mass transfer of CO and NO. Ru single atoms supported on Fe-substituted MgAl2O4 spinel (FMAO) catalyst were prepared by physical mixing for N2O decomposition [132]. Ru1/FMAO SAC calcined at 900 °C (Ru1/FMAO_900) displayed higher activity than Ru/FMAO catalyst calcined at 500 °C because Ru aggregates into single atoms at high temperatures which led to strong metal-support interaction between Fe and Ru. Ru1/FMAO_900 SAC exhibited higher activity than Ru1/Fe2O3 SAC due to its higher redox activity and surface area. Ru1/FMAO_900 SAC exhibited remarkable stability at 550 °C for N2O decomposition at low concentration maintaining N2O conversion of about 76% for 100 h on-stream. HAADF-STEM, elemental and XRD analyzes confirmed no Ru nanoparticles or nanocluster was found in Ru1/FMAO_900 SAC post-reaction indicating that Ru single was highly stable in Ru1/FMAO_900 with no loss of Ru. 3.7 Catalytic propane dehydrogenation A series of γ-alumina supported platinum/copper single atom alloy catalysts were prepared by co-impregnation with different Cu/Pt proportions [133]. In propane selective dehydrogenation over CuxPt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts at different Cu/Pt ratios, the propane conversion increases as the atomic ratio of Cu/Pt of the catalyst increases from 30 to 200. Then the propane conversion remains unaffected as the atomic ratio of Cu/Pt of the catalyst further increases to 460. While CuxPt/γ-Al2O3 SAA catalysts with small loading of Pt exhibited propylene selectivity of ≥ 80% (Table 5). The conversion of propane over Cu200Pt/γ-Al2O3 SAA catalyst was 41% at 600 °C which is higher than 32% for Ag200Pt/γ-Al2O3 SAA catalyst. The Ag200Pt/γ-Al2O3 SAA catalyst was low due to fewer Pt atoms exposed over Ag nanoparticles’ surface. The Cu302Pt/γ-Al2O3 SAA catalyst exhibited remarkable stability over 120 h of reaction operation while maintaining propylene selectivity of 88% under 1 bar at 520 °C. 3.8 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of methyl glycolate Pt single atoms on Cu nanoparticles supported on silica catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method [134]. Hydrogenolysis of methyl glycolate over CuxPt/SiO2 SAA catalysts with different Pt loading revealed that the best mass Cu/Pt ratio of the SAA catalyst was 39; higher or lower Pt loading all ended in decreased ethanol selectivity. The Pt in Cu356Pt/SiO2 SAA catalyst occurred as isolated single atoms which assist to activate H2 alongside preventing C-C cleavage reaction caused by Pt nanoparticles thereby improving its stability. Over a 700 h-time on stream, Cu356Pt/SiO2 SAA maintained complete conversion in hydrogenolysis of methyl glycolate and did not show any deactivation indicating very good catalytic stability. 3.9 Fischer–Tropsch process Ru single atom anchored on Co nanoparticles (Ru1Con) catalyst was synthesized using a 2-dimensional confinement strategy [135]. Ru1Con SAC displayed higher catalytic activity (CO conversion = 62% and C5+ selectivity = 86.7%) in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction than Ru/Co nanoparticles (CO conversion = 33% and C5+selectivity = 69.2%) and Co nanoparticles (CO conversion = 22% and C5+ selectivity = 60.8%) catalysts. The single-atom Ru decreases the rate-limiting barriers of C-O splitting and chain processes. The Ru1Con SAC was exposed to 816 h-test at 150 °C for FTS reaction in which the hydrocarbon selectivity and conversion of CO yielded no notable changes. 4 Conclusion and outlook Single-atom catalyst is a new variety of heterogeneous catalysts comprising dispersed isolated metal atoms on the surface of the support materials. These catalysts exhibit highly recommendable properties such as high selectivity, high catalytic stability and durability, and best noble metal utilization. This review summarizes the latest progress made in the last ∼ 10 years in the preparation and thermocatalytic activities of single-atom catalysts in the conversion of air pollutants and other gases. Since they have distinct active sites and high selectivity makes SAC is similar to homogeneous catalysts. While conventional heterogeneous catalysts have low selectivity due to unclear active sites but they are highly stable at high temperatures. SAC has the combined properties of both homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts in that it has highly exposed active metal sites and are have high thermal stability. This makes SAC the ideal model catalyst for application in the industry. There are still several challenges in SAC that needs to be solved; i Although many SACs have been synthesized, there is still a massive challenge in preparing high-loading noble metal single-atom catalysts. This is because increasing the mass of metal leads to agglomeration which leads to the formation of nanoparticle catalysts. One possible solution is creating numerous defeat sites in the support material to stabilize the isolated metal atom and prevent agglomeration or the use of stabilizing agents such as ionic liquids [104] and alkali stabilizers [38] to protect the isolated metal atoms from aggregation and sintering. ii Even though several works have been done on SAC synthesis, there is still a big challenge in the controllable large-scale preparation of SAC. Some attempts [90,136] have been made for pilot production of SACs but they exhibited poor dispersion of the isolated metal atoms. iii Notwithstanding the application of SAC in gas-phase reactions, there is yet to be a proper understanding of the reaction mechanism over SACs as compared to nanoparticle catalysts. There is a need for in situ characterization to deduce the role of dispersed metal atoms in the reaction mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic gas-phase reactions have gained industrial applicability in the production of chemicals, fuels, and environmental remediation. However, conventional heterogeneous catalysts for gas-phase reactions contain precious metals, which have low utilization efficiency of metal atoms and are expensive, and therefore need to be improved to achieve industrial scalability. Therefore, single-atom catalysis has emerged as a new paradigm for dispersing isolated noble metals on a suitable support material. Herein, this review analyzed recent advances in single-atom catalysts (SACs) for oxidation of carbon monoxide, abatement of formaldehyde, reduction of nitrogen oxides, and hydrogenation of carbon dioxide. Various synthesis methods of different SACs were elucidated and highlighted for the thermochemical gas-phase reactions. Furthermore, the mechanism, challenges, and prospects of the SACs for gas-phase reactions were described. This review is significant to serve as a reference for current and prospective thermochemical gas-phase reactions driven by SACs.
coredata.dc:title: Single-atom catalysts for thermochemical gas-phase reactions
